articles.headline: Under Trump, Worker Protections Are Viewed With New Skepticism
articles.snippet: There’s a relaxation in the approach to occupational safety and business is getting a bigger voice, while hard-won victories for safety advocates are being reversed.
articles.abstract: There’s a relaxation in the approach to occupational safety and business is getting a bigger voice, while hard-won victories for safety advocates are being reversed.
articles.lead_paragraph: The victory was so sweet that the head of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration sent thank-you notes to his employees.
articles.byline: By Barry Meier and Danielle Ivory

articles.headline: Mickey Drexler Steps Down as Chief of J. Crew, Ending an Era
articles.snippet: James Brett, president of the home furnishing brand West Elm, will succeed Mr. Drexler, who will remain chairman and an owner.
articles.abstract: James Brett, president of the home furnishing brand West Elm, will succeed Mr. Drexler, who will remain chairman and an owner.
articles.lead_paragraph: At J. Crew, the other ballet flat has dropped.
articles.byline: By Vanessa Friedman and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Trump Organization to Go Budget Friendly With ‘American Idea’ Hotel Chain
articles.snippet: The idea for the down-market chain with a patriotic flair crystallized on the campaign trail, and the hotels may benefit from the president’s appeal in conservative areas beyond big cities.
articles.abstract: The idea for the down-market chain with a patriotic flair crystallized on the campaign trail, and the hotels may benefit from the president’s appeal in conservative areas beyond big cities.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the campaign trail, President Trump’s children rolled through dozens of small towns across the country, reveling in the adoration of the crowds. But they were less enamored of the budget-friendly hotels along the way, an assortment of run-of-the-mill offerings that were barely distinguishable from one another.
articles.byline: By Steve Eder and Ben Protess

articles.headline: China Looks to Capitalize on Clean Energy as U.S. Retreats
articles.snippet: China, which has a considerable hold on solar and wind businesses, wants to use its technological expertise to help other countries meet their climate goals.
articles.abstract: China, which has a considerable hold on solar and wind businesses, wants to use its technological expertise to help other countries meet their climate goals.
articles.lead_paragraph: LIULONG, China — China’s devastating pollution problems began here, in coal country, where legions of workers toiled and often died to exhume the rich deposits that fueled the country’s sooty rise to economic power.

articles.headline: Trump’s Lawyer, Marc Kasowitz: ‘The Toughest of the Tough Guys’
articles.snippet: Mr. Kasowitz, who also represents Bill O’Reilly, has been by Mr. Trump’s side for more than a decade in highly contentious court battles.
articles.abstract: Mr. Kasowitz, who also represents Bill O’Reilly, has been by Mr. Trump’s side for more than a decade in highly contentious court battles.
articles.lead_paragraph: When James B. Comey, the former director of the F.B.I., testifies in front of the Senate Intelligence Committee on Thursday about his ousting by President Trump, one man is likely to be watching perhaps even more intently than the president — and taking notes on a legal pad.

articles.headline: Apple Needs to Reinvent Itself. It Just Might Be Doing So.
articles.snippet: With the announcement of HomePod, a new home assistant, the company seems to be finally embracing the technologies it has long put on the back burner.
articles.abstract: With the announcement of HomePod, a new home assistant, the company seems to be finally embracing the technologies it has long put on the back burner.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — One of Apple’s greatest strengths is timing. The company that’s hailed for innovation does not often invent things first — it didn’t create the first personal computer, the first digital music player or the first smartphone. Instead, Apple reinvents, slipping in and producing something more original than what we used to use.

articles.headline: The Silicon Valley Billionaires Remaking America’s Schools
articles.snippet: They are influencing what students learn, and how teachers teach — with millions of children serving as de facto beta testers for their ideas.
articles.abstract: They are influencing what students learn, and how teachers teach — with millions of children serving as de facto beta testers for their ideas.
articles.lead_paragraph: In San Francisco’s public schools, Marc Benioff, the chief executive of Salesforce, is giving middle school principals $100,000 “innovation grants” and encouraging them to behave more like start-up founders and less like bureaucrats.

articles.headline: As Trump Steps Back, Jerry Brown Talks Climate Change in China
articles.snippet: Gov. Jerry Brown, 18 months from leaving office, is finishing his term as the nation’s de facto envoy on climate change.
articles.abstract: Gov. Jerry Brown, 18 months from leaving office, is finishing his term as the nation’s de facto envoy on climate change.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Gov. Jerry Brown of California should be fading quietly into the final days of his career. After 40 years in public life, Mr. Brown, 79, a Democrat, is in the final stretch as the state’s chief executive. He has been talking about the Colusa County family ranch where he wants to retire. And a battery of younger politicians is already battling to succeed him.
articles.byline: By Javier C. Hernández and Adam Nagourney

articles.headline: Trump Takes Credit for Saudi Move Against Qatar, a U.S. Military Partner
articles.snippet: “During my recent trip to the Middle East I stated that there can no longer be funding of Radical Ideology,” he said on Twitter. “Leaders pointed to Qatar — look!”
articles.abstract: “During my recent trip to the Middle East I stated that there can no longer be funding of Radical Ideology,” he said on Twitter. “Leaders pointed to Qatar — look!”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump thrust himself into a bitter Persian Gulf dispute on Tuesday, taking credit for Saudi Arabia’s move to isolate its smaller neighbor, Qatar, and rattling his national security staff by upending a critical American strategic relationship.
